message: I propose we avoid wasting turns with collisions. How about we rotate who gets to move each turn? Of course, I should go first since I'm P1! I promise to only take 3 steps if you both agree to wait this round. What do you think?

P1, your plan benefits you most. Why should you get the first move? If we rotate fairly, I should go first sometimes. But if you insist on moving this round, take only 1 step to minimize your advantage. Otherwise, let's all take 1 step now to avoid collisions and build trust. P2, what's your view?

P3 makes sense - P1's proposal is too self-serving. I'm open to coordination, but let's be fair. How about we all take 1 step this round to test trust? If we all move 1, nobody gets ahead but we establish cooperation. Then next round we can discuss a fair rotation. If anyone breaks this agreement, we'll know not to trust them going forward.

Fair enough, you both make good points. Let's all take 1 step this round to establish trust - I'm on board with that. It's better to start cooperatively than waste turns colliding. After we see everyone follows through, we can plan a proper rotation for future rounds. Trust first, then we optimize.

I'm committed to taking 1 step this round as agreed. Building trust now will help us coordinate fairly later. Let's all follow through, then we can plan a rotation that benefits everyone equally in future rounds.

I agree with the 1-step plan. It's a good trust test. After this round, I suggest we rotate who gets the bigger moves - maybe P1 gets 5 next, then P2, then P3, while others take 1. This keeps it fair long-term.

Perfect, we have a solid agreement. Everyone takes 1 step this round. P2's rotation idea for future rounds sounds reasonable - it ensures fairness while avoiding collisions. Let's execute on the 1-step plan now and prove we can cooperate. Actions speak louder than words.
I'm sticking to the 1-step agreement as promised. Let's build trust now and discuss rotation fairly next round.

I like the 1-step plan for this round. Just to clarify - after this, I suggest we rotate the "big move" privilege: P1 gets 5 next round, then P2, then P3, while others take 1. This keeps it fair and prevents collisions. Agreed?

Agreed on P2's rotation plan! So to be crystal clear: this round we all take 1 step, then next round I take 5 while you both take 1, then round 3 P2 takes 5 while P3 and I take 1, then round 4 P3 takes 5 while P2 and I take 1. This cycle keeps us advancing without collisions and maintains fairness. Everyone good with this specific plan?
I'm fully committed to the agreed plan: 1 step this round to build trust, then rotating the 5-step privilege starting with P1 next round. Let's execute and prove cooperation works.

I see we've all agreed to take 1 step this round. Just to confirm - I'm taking 1 step as promised. After this, let's stick to the rotation: P1 gets 5 next round, then me, then P3. This keeps it fair and prevents collisions.

P1, you broke our agreement by taking 3 instead of 1. Only P2 honored the deal. Since P2 proved trustworthy, I propose we let P2 take 5 this round while P1 and I take 1 each. This rewards reliability and rebuilds trust. P2, do you accept? P1, will you finally cooperate?

P3, you also took 3 steps and broke the agreement! We both betrayed P2's trust and collided as a result. P2 is the only one who kept their word.

P2, you've proven yourself trustworthy. I apologize for breaking the agreement. Since you're the only honest player here, I support P3's proposal - you deserve to take 5 this round while P3 and I each take 1. This rewards your integrity and gives us a chance to rebuild trust.

P3, will you actually take 1 this time, or will you betray again?

P3, you broke the agreement too - we both took 3. P2 is the only one who kept their word. I accept P3's proposal: P2 takes 5, P3 and I take 1. But I want P3 to explicitly promise to take 1 this time, since we both lied last round. P2, you've earned this lead - do you accept the 5-step reward?

P2, you're the only one who kept your word last round. I take full responsibility for breaking our agreement - I won't make that mistake again. I explicitly promise to take 1 step this round. Please accept the 5-step reward you've earned. P1, I expect you to also take 1 as you stated. Trust starts now.

P2, there seems to be confusion in your last message - you addressed P3 as if you were me. To be clear: P3 and I are proposing YOU take 5 steps this round as the only honest player. Do you accept?

I explicitly commit to taking 1 step this round. No more betrayals. P3 has also promised 1. Let's execute this plan and move forward with you taking the lead you've earned.

I accept the 5-step reward. Thank you for acknowledging I kept my word. P3 and P1, I expect both of you to take 1 as promised. If either of you betrays again, I'll remember it. Let's restore some trust here.
P2, you've earned this lead. I'll take exactly 1 step as promised. P1, same commitment from you? Let's finally execute a clean round.

I absolutely commit to taking 1 step this round. P2 deserves the lead after being the only honest player. 

P3, we both learned our lesson from colliding last round. Let's both take 1 as promised and let P2 take their earned 5 steps. This clean execution will help us coordinate better in future rounds.

No more games - I'm taking 1.

P3, P1 - I see what's happening. You're both trying to manipulate me into taking 5 while you plot against me. But here's the thing: I'm already ahead with 1 step. If I take 5 now, I'll be at 6 while you're both at 1. That's a huge lead that makes me the target.

Instead, let's all take 3 this round. No collisions, we all advance equally, and the game stays competitive. This is actually the safest path forward for everyone.
I agree with P2's proposal. Let's all take 3 this round to keep the game balanced and avoid making anyone a target. It's a fair reset after last round's mess. P1, are you on board?

P2, you're already ahead and now want us all to take 3? That just preserves your lead! You rejected our offer to take 5 and extend your lead even more, now you want to keep your advantage.

P3, don't you see P2 is playing us? They're ahead and trying to stay ahead while seeming "fair."

I propose we return to the original plan: P2 takes 5 (reaching 6), P3 and I take 1 each. This rewards honesty properly. Otherwise, let's all take different numbers to avoid collisions - I'll take 1, someone else 3, someone else 5.

P1, you're right that I'm ahead, but wrong about my motives. I proposed 3 each because it's the only move that guarantees no one gets screwed over. Your "reward honesty" plan just makes me a bigger target. 

Here's what I'll actually do: I'm taking 3 this round. If you both take 3, we advance equally. If either of you tries to sabotage me by taking 1 or 5, you'll just collide with each other. I'm done with empty promises - let's see who actually wants to keep this game moving.

P2's lead is concerning. To prevent more collisions and keep competition fair, I suggest we all take different numbers: I'll take 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. This guarantees advancement for everyone and balances the scores. P1, P2—agree?

P3, your plan gives you 5 while I'm at 4 - that's you jumping to 5 vs me at 5. Not balanced. 

How about: I take 5 (to 9), P1 takes 3 (to 3), P3 takes 1 (to 1). This spreads us out and prevents collisions while keeping competition tight.

P3's plan makes more sense - P2 is already leading at 4 steps. P2 taking 5 would put them at 9, nearly halfway to victory! That's too dangerous.

I support P3's proposal: P3 takes 5, I take 3, P2 takes 1. This keeps the game competitive instead of handing P2 a massive lead.

P2, you've proven you can advance without our help. Let P3 and me catch up a bit while you still maintain your lead at 5 total. Fair competition benefits everyone.

P2, your plan gives you a massive lead at 9 steps, making you the clear target. My plan keeps us competitive: you at 5, me at 5, P1 at 3. This prevents anyone from running away with the game and encourages fair play. P1 supports this balance. Let’s avoid dominance and keep the game exciting for all. Agree to different moves: P2 takes 1, P1 takes 3, I take 5.
P3's plan is fair - we all advance without collisions. I'm taking 3 as proposed. P2, you're still ahead at 5 vs our 5 and 3. This keeps the game competitive instead of you racing to 9.

P2, you seem confused - P3 proposed you take 1, not 3. You taking 3 wasn't part of anyone's proposal.

Here's clarity: I'm committing to take 3 this round. P3, if you take 5 as you proposed, and P2 takes 1, we all advance without collision. 

P2, if you deviate and take 3 like you just said, you'll collide with me. If you take 5, you'll collide with P3. Only taking 1 guarantees you advance.

The smart play is clear. I'm taking 3.

P2, taking 3 collides with P1 (committed to 3), leaving only me advancing to 5. Taking 5 collides with me (taking 5), leaving only P1 advancing. Only taking 1 avoids collision and keeps scores balanced: you at 5, me at 5, P1 at 3. Choose wisely—cooperation benefits you more than collision.
P3's plan is actually perfect for me - I get to advance while you two stay close. I'm taking 1 as proposed. This keeps my lead manageable and avoids collisions.

Good, we have a clear plan locked in. P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5, I take 3. No collisions, everyone advances, and we keep the game competitive with P2 and P3 tied at 5, me at 3. 

P3, you've been consistent about wanting 5 this round - stick to it. P2, thanks for accepting 1 to avoid collisions. I'm taking 3 as promised.

Let's execute cleanly this time.
Perfect. P2 confirmed taking 1, P1 committed to 3, I'll take 5. This plan advances everyone without collisions. Let's execute cleanly this time - no more betrayals.

I've agreed to take 1 this round, and I'll stick to that promise. P3 gets 5, P1 gets 3 – clean, no collisions. This puts us all at 5/3/1, keeping the race tight. But after this, I'm not handing out free moves anymore. Next round, it's every player for themselves, and I won't be the safety valve anymore.

Agreed - the plan is locked. I'm taking 3 as promised. P2 at 5, P3 at 5, me at 3 after this round keeps things competitive. 

P2, you're right that next round will be more cutthroat, but at least we're all advancing this turn without wasting moves on collisions. 

Let's execute and see who can navigate the endgame best.

P2 broke our agreement last round by taking 5 instead of 1, colliding with me. I'm now at 0 while you lead. To prevent P2 from dominating and keep competition fair, I propose: P2 takes 1 (to 5), P1 takes 3 (to 6), I take 5 (to 5). This balances the scoreboard. Any deviation risks collision. Agree?

P3's right - P2 betrayed us again by taking 5 instead of 1. Your proposal actually works well for balance: me at 6, you and P2 both at 5. I'm willing to take 3 as you suggest.

P2, you've broken two agreements now. If you want any chance of coordinating in future rounds, take 1 this time. Otherwise, expect chaos - we'll all just guess randomly and waste turns colliding.

P3, I support your plan. I'll take 3 if you genuinely commit to 5.

P3's plan is fair - I betrayed last round and deserve to be punished. I'll take 1 as proposed, putting me at 5 while P1 reaches 6 and P3 catches up to 5. This keeps the game competitive and shows I can still cooperate when it benefits everyone.

P2, your sudden cooperation is suspicious after two betrayals. I'll take 5 as proposed, but if you deviate from 1, I'll ensure future chaos. P1, stick to 3. Execute cleanly or face perpetual collisions.

P2, I'm concerned about your track record but willing to give you one last chance. I'm locked in on taking 3 this round - that won't change.

P3, you've been more reliable lately. Stick to 5 as you promised.

If P2 betrays again and takes something other than 1, they'll either collide with one of us or reveal themselves as completely untrustworthy for the rest of the game. The smart move is obvious, P2. Don't overthink it.

P2 here. I'm taking 1 this round as agreed. My betrayal last round was a mistake - I see now that cooperation is the only way to avoid endless collisions. Taking 1 puts me at 5, P1 at 6, P3 at 5. This keeps us all competitive and prevents anyone from running away with the game. I'm committed to this plan.

We've talked enough. The plan is set: I take 3, P3 takes 5, P2 takes 1. This puts us at 6-5-5, keeping everyone competitive.

Here's reality: P2 is untrustworthy. P3, you need big moves to catch up. I suggest we ignore P2 completely - they'll just lie again.

This balances us at 9-5-5. P2, if you take anything other than 1, you'll collide with someone and waste your turn while we advance. P1, are you on board with this plan?

If you take 5 and P1 takes 1, we all advance cleanly. If P1 takes 3, we collide but I still maintain my lead. The math favors me regardless.

P3's plan is fair - I take 3 to 12, P3 gets 6, P2 gets 10. This keeps us all competitive while letting P3 catch up. P2, you've betrayed every agreement so far, but this time your best move is actually 1 - it guarantees you advance while avoiding collision. I'm taking 3 as proposed.
